entry.title: üü£ Create a Case in Service Cloud V2 by Uploading Images Using AI Core, Build Apps
entry.content:
In this demo, we showcase an intelligent self-service portal built using SAP Build Apps, and integrated with SAP Service Cloud V2 and SAP AI Core. What's the magic?
 
Users can raise service requests by simply uploading an image through the portal, triggering a case creation in Service Cloud V2. Leveraging SAP AI Core, the uploaded image is analyzed to detect key objects or issues, and the service ticket description is auto-updated with intelligent insights. AI sentiment analysis is applied to the description, helping to prioritize and categorize cases more effectively. This end-to-end workflow shows how low-code tools and AI-driven automation can transform customer service experiences by reducing manual effort, improving accuracy, and accelerating resolution time.

entry.title: FAGLGVTR and FAGL_PT_02 in Portugal !
entry.content:
Hello,

*** S/4 Hana Private Cloud ***

I'm a bit confused how to use this two transactions in Portugal.

FAGLGVTR - Balance carryforward. Is it only to move the balance sheet accounts balance to the new fiscal year? why do I have to configure OB53 ? I saw some configurations in other companies using the GL account 811* but i thought it was only on the next transaction FAGL_PT_02

FAGL_PT_02 - Should I use to move from the balance from p&l accounts to 811* and then 818* and finally 56* ? Anyway I can't to all the postings  ate the same time since I would need to activate a new function for PT.

The PT company is under a foreign group so it means they use operational COA with alternative account (COA PT).

Can you please give some tips.

Thank you.

Andreia

entry.title: GRC BRM: Update of OVM Landscape
entry.content:
Hi Community,

We created OVMs for a specific landscape and used these OVMs to derive roles. Due to the migration of systems to Google Cloud, the customer now requires us to create a new landscape and import all roles from the original landscape to the new one. The original landscape will then be archived and no longer used.
However, it is not possible to change the landscape in OVM. After importing into the new landscape, the derived roles would contain OVM that belong to a different landscape. Is there any way to change the landscape in OVM?

Thank you in advance for your answer.

entry.title: Re: Functional Specification
entry.content:
It cannot be explained just like that how to write FS and over by years, you will gain knwoledge on that but I can share some tips how your FS should be:

  • Be precise: Avoid vague terms like ‚Äúetc.‚Äù or ‚Äúas needed‚Äù
  • Use SAP terminology: Refer to transactions (e.g., ME2N), tables (e.g., EBAN), and fields clearly
  • Think like a user: Describe how the report or enhancement will be used in daily operations
  • Collaborate with ABAPers: Ask what technical details they need ‚Äî it improves clarity
  • Include screenshots or mockups: Visuals help developers understand layout expectations


With the above, let me give you one example scenario for you to prepare FS

So the Business requirement is to create a custom report to list all open Purchase Requisitions by plant and material group, with selection fields for purchasing group and date range.

For the above requirement, start the FS with the above tips as much as possible. In fact, I would recommend you sit with your ABAP colleague and take the inputs across the table. Because, it is always effective with one to one personal discussion.  Then only, you will understand why certain tables can be considered and why not others while brainstorming. This approach will be more effective than asking in forum.

entry.title: Re: Warehouse number created wrongly with 3 digits, is th...
entry.content:
Hi,
As per standard practice, once the warehouse (WH) has been created and saved, please ensure that no additional configurations have been made and no documents have been posted against it. If that's the case, proceed to delete the existing warehouse and create a new one.

Also, you may proceed with the 3-Digit code.

Please note: Warehouse Management (WM) supports 3-digit warehouse numbers, whereas Extended Warehouse Management (EWM) allows 4-digit codes.

Best Regards,

Aman

Regards

Selva

entry.title: üü£ Leverage Joule Studio to Implement Custom Joule Skills for Smart Customer Advisory Companion
entry.content: Customer support consultants often spend more time navigating/switching systems than delivering value. In this session, we dive straight into a real-world use case: building a "Smart Customer Advisory Companion" that work alongside consultants and assist them to accomplish their task faster using SAP Joule Studio. We'll show you how we transformed a consultant's time-consuming, manual workflow into an intelligent, conversational experience.

entry.title: Thumbs Up for the New ‚ÄúKudos Received‚Äù Progression Badges!
entry.content:
The members have spoken. The relaunch of our progression badge sets is a hit!

We started last week by rolling out four new badges that reward members for providing solutions to questions. Response to my announcement in What‚Äôs New has been extremely positive.  ‚ÄúBringing Back Badges to Reward Q&A Experts!‚Äù has thousands of views and dozens of kudos. Good thing for me, because the next progression set celebrates members for the number of kudos they received ‚Äì so all those recent kudos sure will come in handy toward my progress!

Whether you call them a thumbs-up (as they appear in the site design), a like (as they were known in the previous SAP Community platform), or a kudo (as they‚Äôre called in our current platform), you know that your content has found an audience when members take the time to click that lovely little icon to show their appreciation for your contribution. And we know you‚Äôre the kind of member who deserves special gamification rewards!

As with the ‚Äúsolutions‚Äù badge set, this new set will have five badges in total, although the first badge has been available since the launch of our latest community platform last year. We‚Äôve added four more badges to this set, and you progress based on the number of kudos received. Per the image below, the second badge requires 50 kudos, the third requires 100, the fourth requires 200, and the fifth requires 500.

We‚Äôll launch these badges at some point tomorrow, Thursday, August 28, one at a time over a period of a few hours. Depending on how many kudos you‚Äôve received, don‚Äôt be surprised if you get multiple notifications as the badge assignment occurs during this period. (If you‚Äôre still waiting by Friday, August 29, try logging out and in again. Any new badges should show up then.)

Once again, we‚Äôll award these badges retroactively. Any numbers migrated from the previous platform to this one count toward your progress, and kudos for any content type (e.g., blog post, comment) count as well. So if you‚Äôve been contributing popular content for years, you may have done enough to earn all five badges.

Wondering if you‚Äôre already part of the ‚Äú500+ kudos received‚Äù club? You can check for yourself in your ‚ÄúMy content‚Äù area. In my last post, I provided instructions about how to find your content, but here‚Äôs a reminder for your convenience.

First, make sure you‚Äôve logged in. Click on the person icon in the upper right of any community page. Select ‚ÄúMy content‚Äù from the dropdown.

‚ÄúKudos received‚Äù appears in the gray box at the very top. To help illustrate, I‚Äôm once again relying on the anonymous member who appeared in last week‚Äôs post, by sharing a screenshot from his ‚ÄúMy content‚Äù page. (He didn‚Äôt complain then, so I hope he doesn‚Äôt mind now. Or maybe he just hasn‚Äôt noticed yet.)

Looks like this community veteran has received thousands of kudos over the years ‚Äì more than enough to rack up all four badges tomorrow.

How about you? If you‚Äôre expecting all four of the new badges tomorrow, then kudos to you! (Pun intended.) Whether you receive one, five, or any number in between, we appreciate your involvement in SAP Community. More importantly, our members appreciate your activity ‚Äì evidenced by all their kudos for you!

If you don‚Äôt get a badge (or get one or some but want them all), you‚Äôll have plenty of opportunity in future to complete the set. All you need to do is continue to contribute quality content to SAP Community. If members like what you‚Äôre sharing, you can eventually accrue enough kudos to work your way through this new progression set.

Not the kind of member who likes to publish content? That‚Äôs OK. We have more progression badge sets coming in the weeks ahead, and not all of them depend on posting to SAP Community. There are lots of things members can do to create a positive community, and we‚Äôll be awarding badges for those, too.

Look for updates here in the What‚Äôs New section to learn how you can receive gamification rewards as we introduce new progression sets. One thing is certain: The more you do in SAP Community, the more badges you can earn. My advice if you‚Äôre a badge hunter? Stay active. Stay engaged. In short, stay an important part of SAP Community. We look forward to recognizing all members who make our community a better place!

entry.title: üü£ Taking guided experiences with SAP Build to the next level
entry.content: SAP Build Guided Experience‚Äù powered by SAP Build Work Zone and SAP Build Process Automation is an intuitive user interface to guide you through a sequence of steps or actions enabling business users to simplify complex business processes into self-service journeys. Guided Experiences help navigate through complex business processes such as parental leave, benefits enrollment, employee relocation, new hire or supplier onboarding, training and enablement, or browsing and & purchasing electronic equipment. Users can model intuitive stages and stages which can by further enriched with content, documents, forms, UI cards and more. Stay tuned to deep-dive into its capabilities!

entry.title: üü£ From Clicks to Code: Automate SAP BTP Setup with Terraform
entry.content: This session introduces developers to the world of Infrastructure as code, as we explore Terraform and the Terraform Providers for SAP BTP and Cloud Foundry. We‚Äôll start with the fundamentals of Terraform and explore how it enables consistent, repeatable, and version-controlled resource management. This will be done through a simple and practical hands on scenario where we will configure SAP BTP and deploy an app on Cloud Foundry -- all through code. This session will equip the participants with the ability to streamline their deployment workflows.

entry.title: Re: ABAP RAP - Global Authorization
entry.content:
Hi,

Hiding the Create button can be achieved by commenting out use create; in the behavior definition for the interface view and keep create ( features: global ); in the consumption view. 

// use create; "Comment out in behaviour definition in interface view

create ( features : global ); "Keep create in behaviour definition for consumption view

entry.title: MDG upgrade from 1909 to MDG 2023 - UIBB Customizations overwritten
entry.content:
Hello All, 

After upgrading our MDG system from 1909 to 2023, we have observed the following issues:
‚Ä¢ All UIBBs and fields are now visible, including those that were previously hidden.
‚Ä¢ Our customized fields and configurations seem to be overwritten by the standard SAP delivery.
‚Ä¢ The customizations still exist in the system, but instead of showing our configured fields, the standard fields are now appearing.

Question:
Post-upgrade, will all customizations made on top of standard configurations (UIBBs, hidden fields, etc.) be overwritten in 2023?
What is the recommended approach to preserve or reapply these customizations after an upgrade?

Thanks in advance for your insights.

entry.title: Re: Evaluating Risks of Non-VPN Access to SAP BTP Cockpit
entry.content:
Hi

Instead of use S-Users yo should integrate with your IDP. It has many benefits: https://help.sap.com/docs/btp/sap-business-technology-platform/bringing-your-corporate-identity-provider-for-platform-users

in this scenario the Platform Users will access BTP Cockpit via IAS and then you usually configure IAS to your corporate IDP. In this scenario you can apply some rules in IAS itself (if you're not using custom IDP) or if you're using Entra or simmilar you have the ability to block the access to the app by a wide set of criterias (device, location, risk, etc).

You should keep the access with S-User to your cockpit only to a limited number of users or maybe only to a Emergency user. You should keep at least one for emergency scenarios.

E.g., as soon as I type sel it shows a proposal for select). This happens constantly and interrupts typing.

 

I would like to keep Suggest keywords (very helpful) but without that modal dialog.

Is anyone else facing this issue?

Thanks.

entry.title: Re: How to do budgets for purchase in sap s4 hana public...
entry.content:
Budgeting for Purchase (Procurement)

To manage procurement budgets, you‚Äôll typically use cost center budgeting and availability control:

1) Define Budget-Relevant G/L Accounts

In the G/L master data, flag accounts as budget-relevant under the Public Sector Management Data tab.

2) Create Budget Documents

Use the Manage Budget Documents Fiori app to enter budgets manually. You can also upload budgets via Excel or integrate with SAP Analytics Cloud.

3) Assign Budgets to Cost Centers

Budgets are linked to cost centers, funds, or functional areas depending on your setup.

4) Enable Availability Control

This ensures that purchase requisitions and orders are checked against available budget. Only expense-type entries are included in availability control.


Budgeting for Sales (Revenue Planning)

Sales budgeting is more about forecasting and planning than hard availability control:

1) Use SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC)

SAC is the recommended tool for sales planning, revenue projections, and profitability analysis. You can model revenue by product, region, customer group, etc.

2) Integrate with S/4HANA Cloud

Budget data from SAC can be pushed into S/4HANA Cloud using OData services. Revenue budgets can be used for Revenue Increasing Budget (RIB) functionality.

3) Monitor via ACDOCP Table

All budget entries (expense and revenue) are stored in ACDOCP, the central planning table.

entry.title: Configuring SAP Cloud Integration for an IBP to S/4HANA (on prem / private cloud) integration
entry.content:
Hi SAP Community,

Following a first entry blog on introducing SAP Cloud Integration from Integration Services as the new time series ETL for IBP integration, here is a second sharing focusing this time on configuring the Integration Suite to lay the groundwork for integration flow creation.

---------------

 Again, to all customers/partners out there working with CI-DS : there is currently no plan to sunset CI-DS, it will continue to be supported by SAP in the future.

---------------

Before proceeding, please make sure you meet the below prerequisites.

Prerequisites

  • All steps from my first technical setup blog entry.  
  • The SAP Cloud connector for S/4HANA (on premise or private cloud) has been installed and configured to connect your SAP IBP and SAP S/4HANA instances.
      • More info on installation steps  : SAP BTP Connectivity ‚Äì Installation.
      • More info on the configuration, including how to setup the password for the Administrator user : SAP BTP Connectivity ‚Äì Initial Configuration.
  • Users have been created via the BTP cockpit with the relevant roles depending on what tasks they need to perform. The three typical roles for CI are the following: PI_Administrator, PI_Integration_Developer and PI_Business_Expert. Check the Personas for CI information to understand what each covers in order to assign the most relevant ones.
    • To support actions from this blog entry you need the PI_Integration_Developer role.
  • The SAP S/4HANA, Supply Chain Integration Add-On for SAP Integrated Business Planning is configured in S/4HANA for integration purposes.

 

Defining the Destinations

Before you can begin designing iflows, you must start by defining your source and target systems as you would typically do for CI-DS (Datastore section).

Configure IBP as a Destination

For the Integration Suite, you need to perform this action on the BTP subaccount level of your BTP cockpit.

  • First find the path from your BTP cockpit: Account Explorer > Global Account > Subaccounts tab, and select your subaccount as seen in the previous blog entry on how to setup the technical landscape in BTP.
  • Navigate to the Account Overview screen and select Connectivity > Destinations from the left side panel.
  • Start by creating a destination to model your IBP tenant by selecting the ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù button

  • Choose ‚ÄúFrom scratch‚Äù
  • Then populate at least the following fields:
    • Name, I suggest identifying your IBP destination with its tenant code in the XXX format as shown below,
    • Type : RFC,
    • Description, optional details on the destination can be added,
    • Proxy Type : Internet,
    • Alias User, represents the Communication User created previously in IBP, in our example USR_SAP_COM_931,
    • Password, the password set for the Communication User in IBP,
    • WebSocket RFC Server Host, your IBP tenant url in the format ‚ÄúmyXXXXXX-api.scmibp1.ondemand.com‚Äù,
    • WebSocket RFC Server Port: 443,
    • Client: 100.

  • Click on Create.

To check the connection is setup correctly, you can use the ‚ÄúCheck Connection‚Äù button after saving, located on the top right-hand corner of the Destination configuration screen

You should get the following success message:

Now you need to configure your S/4HANA system as a destination to start building iflows.

 

Configure S/4HANA as a Destination

From the Destinations list,

  • Choose once again ‚ÄúCreate‚Äù and ‚ÄúFrom scratch‚Äù as done to configure the IBP destination.
  • Then populate at least the following fields:
    • Name, I suggest identifying your IBP S/4HANA destination with its tenant and client codes as shown below,
    • Type : RFC,
    • Description, optional details on the destination can be added,
    • Proxy Type : On Premise,
    • User, represents the technical user that must first exist in your S/4HANA system with necessary authorizations assigned (you can use template role SAP_IBPECC_CI_RFC_1.0),
    • Password, the password set for the above technical user in S/4HANA,
    • Location ID, if you set a location ID during the Cloud Connector configuration set the same name here (which you can check in the left side panel: Connectivity > Cloud Connectors),

Example:

 

 In the Target System Configuration section, set the following:

  • Virtual Application Server Host, the virtual host name used during the Cloud Connector configuration (which you can check in the left side panel: Connectivity > Cloud Connectors),

  • System Number, your S/4HANA system number used for this integration,
  • Client, your S/4HANA client used for this integration.

Example:

  • Click on Create.

To check the connection is setup correctly, you can use the ‚ÄúCheck Connection‚Äù button after saving, located on the top right-hand corner of the Destination configuration screen.

You should get the below message:

 

 

Lay the groundwork for building Iflows

Now that the technical setup is completed and connections have been configured and tested, you can proceed with building integration content.

The first thing you‚Äôll need to do is leverage the pre-built integration content delivered by SAP.

Access your Integration Suite tenant, you can do so either with the direct URL or via your BTP cockpit, select your subaccount and from the left side panel Instances and Subscriptions. From there, see below screenshot, find your Integration Suite subscription and find the Go to Application option from the menu.

In the next entries we will focus essentially on these three sections of the Integration Suite:

  • Discover
    This section offers preconfigured packages delivered by SAP that can help accelerate your integration work. A package regroups integration flows (hereafter referred to as iflows), documentation, value mappings and other so-called artifacts to help you cover a specific integration scenario.
  • Design
    The Design section is where you create your iflows. To begin you can copy packages from the Discover section or create a package of your own from scratch.
  • Monitor
    Here you can monitor your executed iflows once deployed.

Let‚Äôs now introduce the preconfigured packages that will be relevant for the IBP ‚Äì S/4HANA (private cloud / on-premise) integration, specifically based on the use of the SAP S/4HANA, Supply Chain Integration Add-On for SAP Integrated Business Planning.

In the Discover section look for the following three packages:

  • SAP IBP - Reusable Integration Flows
  • SAP IBP Add-On - Reusable Integration Flows
  • SAP IBP - Integration with SAP S/4HANA Cloud Private Edition or SAP S/4HANA or SAP ERP

 

 You‚Äôll need to copy each of them into the Design section. To do this, access the first one by clicking on the entry itself which brings you to the content of the package and select ‚ÄúCopy‚Äù.

Do this for the two other packages and now access the Design section to confirm all three have been correctly copied in your working environment.

 

Now any iflows that you will build to support your integration project will necessarily be composed of so-called reusable iflows which are part of these preconfigured packages delivered by SAP.

A reusable iflow is a prebuilt sequence allowing to perform a particular action in a source or target system. Let‚Äôs just say it encapsulates SAP Best Practices in terms of design (necessary checks, logging exception messages, opening and closing a connection to the system, etc.) with a single role that could be reading data from S/4HANA, fetching and posting data in IBP, reading data in IBP or initializing the iflow.

The iflows that you will create, we call them business iflows, will use a series of these reusable iflows depending on what your need done. To be able to execute an iflow, it first needs to be deployed and because your business iflow will incorporate sub iflows including reusable iflows, it is essential all of these are deployed first so let‚Äôs tackle this action.

To deploy you reusable iflows, you need to do the following for all artifacts of both packages SAP IBP - Reusable Integration Flows and SAP IBP Add-On - Reusable Integration Flows:

  • Access the package
  • Navigate to the Artifact tab
  • For each iflow in this section, select the menu (three dots on the right) and click on Deploy

 

  • Click on Yes in the confirmation dialog.

At some point you should get the following notification on the bottom of the screen:

You can also check this in the Monitor section from the left side panel, choose Manage Integration Content

Check the status on the iflow previously deployed.

Again: do this for ALL iflows within the Artifacts tab of BOTH of the reusable iflows packages.

 

In the next blog entry, we shall create a first customer iflow based on reusable iflows to call data from S/4HANA via its integration addon (calling an extractor directly as CI-DS would) and see how we can influence the call via mappings and filters.

Stay Tuned!

 

Sources 

  • Overview of SAP Integration Suite and SAP Cloud Integration
  • Connection setup guide https://me.sap.com/notes/3628813

entry.title: Table maintenance alternatives in S/4HANA on premise
entry.content:
Hi,

We are working on defining best practice guidelines for creating maintenance objects in S/4HANA on promise. Depending on complexity, there seem to be a few options:

  • Using a simple Table Maintenance View from GUI with a Fiori Launchpad tile .
  • Using the Fiori app ‚ÄúCustom Business Objects‚Äù, which generates a BOPF object in the background.
  • Creating a ‚ÄòMaintenance Object‚Äô from Eclipse, which generates a RAP-based solution.

Since SAP provides the Custom Business Objects app, it could be a valid option, but RAP is the strategic direction.

I would appreciate recommendations or best practices on which approach to choose for both small/simple and more complex maintenance/configuration tables. No step-by-step instructions are needed; I am primarily looking for guidance on the preferred approach.

Thanks in advance!

entry.title: Re: Create and update action in custom table while implem...
entry.content:
Hi @Shadab_Hussain67 

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, Cloud BAdIs run under strict transactional contracts. The error you are seeing means that the BAdI you are implementing is defined as FUNCTIONAL. Such BAdIs are read-only and are not allowed to perform database changes such as INSERT, UPDATE, MODIFY and DELETE.

  1. Here is why you Cannot update a Table here
  • badi_mmim_check_matdocitem is a check BAdI.
  • It is intended only for validations during material document item processing.
  • Database updates are not permitted because they would interfere with the posting transaction.
  1. Here is how to handle your Use Case

If you need to persist additional data like yield quantity and validate against it later, you have the two following options:

  1. Make use of a Persistency BAdI / SAVE phase
    • Move your database INSERT/UPDATE logic into a BAdI that supports persistence
    • An example is a post-document processing BAdI such as badi_mmim_post_matdocitem
  2. Decouple Validation from Persistency
    • In the check BAdI, only perform the validation logic. Compare current quantities with what is already stored.
    • For saving additional data, create a separate custom business object using Developer Extensibility or Key User Custom Business Object, and update it in a permitted lifecycle BAdI.
  3. Here is an alternative Event Handling
    • In some scenarios, you can trigger persistence through an RAP Business Event or custom handler attached to a business object extension, rather than directly modifying a table inside a functional BAdI.

Here are references that will provides more details.

BAdIs and Transactional Contracts in S/4HANA Cloud

 

I hope this provides the necessary details. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

For a Discrete Industry/Order execution flow, you might want to evaluate using Packing APIs, to perform the same steps you perform in Work Center POD using Packing POD Plugin. entry.title: Business Intelligence, Analytics & Predictive Analytics for Consultants- Without the Tech Jargon
entry.content:
Breaking into the world of Consulting has never been more exciting. Whether you‚Äôre aiming to specialize in business or cloud technologies, one skillset cuts across all: understanding Business Intelligence and Analytics.  

Why? Because you‚Äôll be advising clients on how to make decisions, and knowing the basics of BI and Analytics enables you to connect technical solutions with real business value, and this is something you can‚Äôt afford to ignore if you want to stand out as a tech consultant in the SAP ecosystem. Read through -> at the end, we‚Äôll share the key resource that connects directly to your next step as a consultant.

What is Business Intelligence (BI), in simple terms? 

Business Intelligence (BI) is all about using tools and procedures to analyze and transform data into meaningful information. The goal? Helping companies make better and faster decisions. Whether it's a sales team spotting trends or the finance department looking for cost-saving opportunities, BI turns data into actionable insights for decision makers.  

Let‚Äôs break it down with a simple example üëá:   

Imagine you are advising a small grocery store with a cash register. After each sale, they print the receipt and pile them up on your desk.  Each receipt provides details like: 

  • What product was sold 
  • The price 
  • The brand 
  • The time of the sale 
  • Which store location 

Now, if all those receipts just sit there in a messy pile without having structure or meaning, it‚Äôs nothing more than clutter!  This is where BI, analytics, and Predictive Analytics come in. By using BI, you can turn the cash register‚Äôs data into simple visuals that show: 

  • Your top-selling products 
  • Peak sales hours 
  • Brands that bring the most profit 
  • Stores that are performing best 

Wow! Now your client can make decisions with information that makes sense and leads to action. Therefore, if you see that soda sales double on Saturdays, you can advise them to stock more and keep folks happy. 

And what are the 5 stages of Business Intelligence? 

  1. Collecting data from your store, customers, etc. 
  2. Storing it in one place (like a database) 
  3. Cleaning and modeling it (Analytics again) 
  4. Visualizing and examining it (BI) 
  5. Taking action with that insight 

 What is the difference between Analytics and BI? 

Analytics is the behind-the-scenes work: gathering all those receipts, cleaning mistakes (like wrong prices or product names), calculating new stuff (like profit or days payable outstanding), and structuring the data so it makes sense. However, Business Intelligence comes after: it‚Äôs visualizing the cleaned data in charts or dashboards, reports, and charts that anyone can understand. 

So, what about Predictive Analytics? 

If BI helps you understand the past and present, Predictive Analytics helps you plan, using past records to predict the future. For example, if December always brings a 40% uptick in chocolate sales, you can predict it‚Äôll happen again and advise your client to prepare for this seasonal demand.  

Types of Predictive Analytics You‚Äôll Encounter 

Depending on what you want to peek into the future, you‚Äôll need to use different approaches:  

  • Regression: Predicting numbers (e.g., next month‚Äôs sales) 
  • Classification: Predicting categories (e.g., ‚ÄúWill this customer churn?‚Äù) 
  • Segmentation: Grouping customers with similar behavior 
  • Time-series: Forecasting trends over time (e.g., seasonal trend sales) 

Now, imagine scaling that grocery store to a multinational retailer client with millions of daily transactions. At that scale, you need robust tools to handle massive amounts of data, and that‚Äôs where SAP comes in. 

  • In SAP Datasphere, you can gather, integrate, and model your cash register data (and other sources) for data analytics. 
  • SAP Analytics Cloud (SAC) turns those models into dashboards, planning tools, and interactive visual stories (known as Intelligent Applications in SAP). This is where BI is done.   
  • SAP Business Data Cloud (BDC), a cloud-native SaaS solution, combines Datasphere, SAC, SAP Business Warehouse (BW), and adds SAP Databricks for advanced AI and machine learning capabilities, allowing you to perform predictive analytics.  

Knowing how these pieces fit together will enable you to communicate confidently with both technical teams and business stakeholders, making you a more valuable consultant. 

üîµReady to kickstart your career as a Consultant in SAP‚Äôs Ecosystem? 

Explore the SAP Digital Skills Center and discover our programs in your region (Only applicable for fresh graduates, unemployed, or underemployed in the EMEA region).  

Co-authored by @ByronCarvajalP and  @lauravalentina_guevaradavila

entry.title: Information and Lifecycle Management; Exception Process for Business Document Retention Periods
entry.content:
We have recently configured Information Lifecycle Management in our environment and maintained Retention Rules for the different document types.

In some cases it will be necessary to retain documents beyond the Retention Period. 

Is there a process which we can use to flag such documents?


------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------
Learn more about the SAP Support user and program here.

entry.title: Re: Information and Lifecycle Management; Exception Proce...
entry.content:
Yes, you can overrule the residence and retention end dates using the Overrule Retention Settings option which you can find in the Lifecycle Items view.

The button should be visible above the table in the Lifecycle Items view; where you would expect to find the Actions button in other views.

More details can be found in the Help Documentation linked below.

https://help.sap.com/docs/SAP_BUSINESS_BYDESIGN/2754875d2d2a403f95e58a41a9c7d6de/75c8834ca357487db84610783f99f670.html?locale=en-US&version=LATEST

entry.title: Algorithm 015 only checks 13 chars (CHECT). How to clear on full reference?
entry.content:
Hi Experts,

We clear outgoing vendor payments via bank transfer. The bank provides a transaction reference (16‚Äì18 characters). Users store the same value in the FI document Assignment (BSEG-ZUONR). On EBS import (MT940) I want clearing to happen based on that full reference.

Configuration:

  • S4 HANA 2021

  • Interpretation algorithm 015 ‚Äì Clearing: transaction selection using assignment.

  • Posting rules and external transactions are assigned as usual.

Problem:
During interpretation/clearing the system seems to evaluate only 13 characters of the reference, so the match fails. In the tables I see FEBEP-CHECT (length 13) being populated; FEBA log shows only the first 13 digits used for selection.

Questions:

  1. Is Algorithm 015 hard-coded to use CHECT (13) instead of ZUONR (18), hence the truncation?

  2. What is the standard way to clear on a full 16‚Äì18 char reference from MT940?

    • Can 015 be made to read the ZUONR value filled via Search String?

    • Or is there another interpretation algorithm that checks ZUONR (18) rather than CHECT?

  3. If customizing cannot achieve this, which enhancement is recommended by SAP?

    • BAdI FIEB_CHANGE_BS_DATA (pre-interpretation) to normalize reference and/or move it, then clear?

    • custom interpretation algorithm to avoid the 13-char limit?

Thanks in advance for guidance on the correct standard approach.

entry.title: Re: Public Cloud TM: prevent freight unit creation for PO...
entry.content: Hi Woflgang, in SAP Cloud Public edition, you can use App Manage Condition to prevent auto creation of Freight Unit

entry.title: Re: I am looking for way to run MD51 project planning in...
entry.content:
One workaround is use MRP Groups for Granular Control. This is the most SAP-standard way to achieve what you're asking.

  • Create MRP Groups in customizing SPRO ‚Üí Production ‚Üí MRP ‚Üí Planning ‚Üí Define MRP Groups
  • Assign different MRP control parameters (planning mode, creation indicators, etc.) to each group
  • In the material master, assign the appropriate MRP Group to materials linked to specific WBS elements

This allows you to run MD51 and have materials behave differently based on their assigned MRP Group ‚Äî even within the same plant.

entry.title: Re: Please let me know CDS views for extractor 0CO_OM_NWA...
entry.content:
Hi @vijay_k1 

In SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, the classic BW extractors like 0CO_OM_NWA_2 for Internal Orders and 0CO_OM_WBS_6 for WBS Elements are replaced by released CDS views.

  1. Replacement for 0CO_OM_NWA_2

Use the released CDS view:

  • I_ActualCostLineItem Actual Cost Line Item ‚Äì Universal Journal
  • Depending on your reporting requirements, you may also use:
    • I_ActualCostLineItemCube, which is the Analytical cube view
    • C_ActualCostLineItemQ2202, which Consumption view for analytics
  1. Replacement for 0CO_OM_WBS_6

Use the released CDS views for project-related postings:

  • I_ActualCostLineItemWBS, which is Actual Cost Line Item by WBS Element
  • Also relevant for analytics:
    • I_ProjectWBSActualCostItemCube
    • C_ProjectWBSActualCostItem, which is the consumption view
  1. Where to Find Them

You can explore these CDS views in your system via:

  • App View Browser, the Fiori ID: F2170
  • App Custom CDS View, Fiori ID: F1866 if you want to build on top of them.

Here are some references that guides you further:

 CDS Views for Universal Journal in S/4HANA Cloud

SAP Community solution: Replacing CO Extractors with CDS Views

 

I hope this provides the necessary details. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Global Feature Contron in RAP, Feature control in RAP
entry.content:
Nice overview about the global feature handling.

There is one usecase where i would like to know if you have a solution for it.

I have a static factory action to control the creation of data for my RAP BO. So in the BDEF it looks like this:

static factory action ( features : global ) s_factory_create_by_ref
parameter ZS_REF_PARAM[1];

And in the Projection like this:

  use action s_factory_create_by_ref;

And i also have an implementation for the FEATURES GLOBAL in my behavior implementation class:

  METHOD m_get_global_features.
    CHECK requested_features IS NOT INITIAL.
    result-%action-s_factory_create_by_ref = if_abap_behv=>fc-o-disabled.
  ENDMETHOD.

My expectation would be, that this is triggert directly before i load any data in my app, but somehow it never gets triggered.

entry.title: Re: Change sales order item to individual stock after mai...
entry.content:
My request is when you create a discussion like this, please also add what the Business requirement is and why you want to change the item category. This will help to assist and show the right direction.

Now coming to your requirement, it sounds like you're trying to ensure that sales order items with a specific delivery priority are managed using sales order individual stock may be with special stock E.

Technically, your idea of changing the item category based on delivery priority is feasible, but before recommending a user exit, it‚Äôs important to understand the business rationale behind this. For example:

  • Is this about ensuring dedicated stock for high-priority customers?
  • Is it to prevent stock from being consumed by other orders?
  • Is it tied to a specific fulfillment or service-level agreement?

Once the business goal is clear, we can explore whether item category substitution is the right path ‚Äî and if so, which enhancement point, or user exit best supports it.

entry.title: Re: SAP Public cloud and Warehouse bin migration object
entry.content:
Hello ST24,

first of all, the answer that you have accepted before is only partially correct.

The Warehouse - Storage bin object is supporting creation of new Bins. I have successfully tested it a few minutes ago in a Public Cloud system. It is not foreseen to update Bins, as the documentation is correctly saying.

The enhanced description (tooltip) is indeed misleading as it was initially build for WM storage bins to be used in objects such as Product, Production Version, Product - Extend. Unfortunately it was also  being reused for the Warehouse - storage bin object.  I have just created a task to get this fixed with the next Publio Cloud CFD release (probably 2508.2). The misleading sentence will be removed. Regarding your error message that you are getting when you try to migrate Warehouse - storage bins, can you please provide the full error message text, the error message ID/class and the error message number. It is then easier to see where you problem comes from. Probably there is either an issue with the configuration or an issue with the data in the template. You can still create a ticket here. But it is definitely possible to create Warehouse storage bins with the migration object.

BR

Frank

entry.title: Re: Table maintenance alternatives in S/4HANA on premise
entry.content:
I was very successful using Maintenance Objects to replace SM30-based transactions. I would not recommend Custom Business Objects because always those UI tools lack functionality that is often needed.

The only drawback I see today on both is those used for customizing activity. There is no out of the box solution to make apps created using those request a customizing transport to move the data to other environments.

Still, I have found some posts here in the SAP Community that people have enhanced their RAP BO by using actions or similar concepts to be able to achieve this with some custom code on the behavior pool class.

It's also possible to create tiles pointing to the Custom Business Configurations app by passing a parameter for a given Maintenance Object. The documentation is not so clear and I was only successful doing that by using the same semantic object + action from the standard app. (#BusinessConfiguration-maintain)

Do you have any idea how to proceed?

entry.title: Re: Change sales order item to individual stock after mai...
entry.content: Thanks for the quick reply. Yes it is about ensuring dedicated stock for high-priority customers.

entry.title: Re: How to do budgets for purchase in sap s4 hana public...
entry.content:
Even without SAC, SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud offers Public Sector Management (PSM) capabilities that allow you to:

1. Define Budget Using Budget Documents
Use the Manage Budget Documents app to manually enter budget amounts. Assign budgets to cost centers, projects (WBS), or funds depending on your setup.

2. Enable Budget Availability Control
This is the key feature that checks whether a PR or PO exceeds the available budget. It works for expense-type G/L accounts ‚Äî and not directly for inventory (balance sheet) accounts. For inventory materials, budget control kicks in at the point of consumption, not at the time of procurement. So the budget validation happens when the material is issued to a cost center or project ‚Äî not when it's received into stock.

3. PR Budget Validation Setup
To enable budget validation for PRs:

  • ensure the account assignment category is set to K (Cost Center), P (Project), or A (Asset) ‚Äî not blank.
  • Maintain PSM account assignments in the PR line item.
  • Activate availability control in the budget configuration for the relevant fund center or cost object.

entry.title: Re: confidential enterprise projects
entry.content:
Hi @tomlovelock 

Your observation is correct, in Enterprise Projects within SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud, there are dedicated fields for controlling visibility and confidentiality, namely Authorisation Group and Confidential Project. These are the recommended mechanisms to restrict access, rather than cost centres.

  1. Authorisation Group
  • The field Authorisation Group in I_EnterpriseProject can be used to classify projects and link them to specific authorisation objects.
  • This enables you to restrict project-related transactions for example financial postings, project planning and billing so that only users with the matching authorisation group in their business role can access them.
  1. Confidential Project Flag
  • The Confidential Project indicator is used for additional visibility control.
  • When marked confidential, access to the project and its related data for example WBS elements, costs, revenues and billing items is further restricted to explicitly assigned project members or authorised business roles.
  1. How to Implement in Public Cloud
  1. Maintain Authorisation Groups
    • Use the Fiori app Manage Your Solution (SSCUI) or the Maintain Authorisation Groups app if it is available in your scope.
    • Assign the groups to projects in the Enterprise Project apps.
  2. Assign to Business Roles
    • In the Maintain Business Roles app, restrict access to Enterprise Project data using the authorisation group field. Example: Role Project Controller, Defence ‚Üí only sees projects with Authorisation Group = DEF.
  3. Confidential Projects
    • When the confidential flag is active, access is limited further.
    • In practice, you assign project members to the confidential project team and only those users and administrators can access the project.

Enterprise Projects (Authorisation and Confidential Projects)

Business Role and Authorisation Concept in S/4HANA Cloud

I hope this provides the necessary details. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Change sales order item to individual stock after mai...
entry.content:
To achieve this, SAP needs to treat the sales order item as requiring individual stock, which is managed under special stock indicator 'E'. This ensures that:

  • Stock is reserved specifically for that sales order
  • MRP and ATP treat it as isolated from unrestricted stock
  • Other orders cannot consume it

In item category configuration let us assume, ZTAE, set "E" against Special Stock indicator.

Next, use USEREXIT_ITEM_CAT_DETERMINATION in program MV45AFZZ to:

  • Read the delivery priority from the sales order item
  • If it matches your high-priority value (e.g., 'H'), substitute the item category to one configured for individual stock. Example: replace TAN with a custom item category ZTAE that supports special stock E.

In OVZG, map the requirement type to a planning strategy that supports special stock. This ensures proper behavior during MRP and availability check.

In my earlier post, I left few more questions which are also critical to address this requirement. They are

  • Should this apply to all customers or only specific ones?
  • Is this needed for all materials or only certain product groups?
  • Is delivery priority maintained at order entry or later?
  • Should the substitution happen only during creation or also during changes?

So for whatever reasons, you need to apply the logic accordingly based on the above queries and you can try with the exit I suggested above
